title: House Day 36 of the 2025 Legislative Session
summary:
Overview: This Georgia House session was focused on recognizing the contributions of long-time state Representative Terry England, as well as the opening prayer and pledge of allegiance.

Key Actions: None detected.

Bills Introduced (First Reading): None detected.

Notable Moments:
- The House recognized the presence of Terry England, a beloved state representative, and celebrated his service and impact.
- The opening prayer was delivered by Reverend Dr. Hugh Ward, who was introduced by Representative Chaz Cannon.

Votes: None detected.

Attendance: A quorum was present, as members were called to the floor to vote their presence.

Adjournment: The session transcript does not indicate when the session was adjourned. The next session date is not provided.
transcript:
All members, all members will please come to the floor. All members, all members please come to the floor. Are we going to, we'll be in session here a little bit. We have some business to attend to for the people of Georgia. So all members of your please come to the floor. Because the hour for convenient having arrived, all members will please come to the floor and take their seats. Mr. Clerk, will you ring the bell? All members, all members please come to the floor and take your seats. We're going to have the morning roll call. All members present will please vote green to signify their presence in the chamber. Mr. Clerk, will you unlock the machines? Mr. Clerk, will you ring the bell? All members, all members, vote if so. Mr. Clerk, will you lock the machines, please? The doorkeepers, will you please close the doors and keep them closed? I'm going to the vote just for a moment. Before we get to our chapel another day, we have another blessing today. That we've been experiencing over the last month or something like that. As one of the most beloved members ever are this chamber. And this Capitol Hill, this Capitol. If you have a seating right down here to my right. A few weeks ago, it's a miracle. Miracles still happen and miracles are continuing. He has some caregivers here with him today. Jamie Shepard's here. His family's done such outstanding work and helped the good Lord perform miracles in so many lives in this state and around the world. So thank you to the Shepherd family. Mr. Lannis Shepard, his grandmother, who founded the Shepherd Center, has made a difference. And thanks for the support from a lot of folks. We'll continue to make a difference in so many lives. Thanks to Jamie and the staff here with you today. We appreciate you all being here. Thanks to the one who really makes it happen. The kind of pushes and shows and pits and embraces and encourages. And that's Cindy England. Let's still see how much we appreciate her. Thank you. Well, that's all just about all I have to say on that. And the words of that wise man, I think that's about all I have to say. But not quite. You should have stayed standing up there, remaining standing up. A man who's really enshrined himself in history of our state in many, many ways I believe. And I think the records of this house and the records of his accomplishments, his friendship as he's built in this room and around our state. And the difference he's made in so many different areas with his compassion, his support as appropriations chair. But mainly as a human of fine, fine human being. We're glad he's having back here today. He'll be back. He's determined. And you can see that. So a friend of all of us in this room, a friend of Georgia, and our dear friend, Terry England. Thank you. Thank you. If you don't think the good Lord works in mysterious ways, this proof of it right there. He's blessed my life as he had so many of y'all's. And his example of in his belief, his strength, meaning the world to me. Thank you, Terry. Thank you for love for all of us and thank you for what you have done and what you will continue to do to make Georgia the best place, live, work and raise a family and have a little fun along the way. So thank you and we appreciate you being here. Now, I know all of you have some of you agreed form a representative chairman, a lot of hats, husband, grandfather, and all those good things. And I'm taking care of so many people in his life and so many different capacities. Terry's going to hang around. He's going to be here for the chaplain. Then he's going to go out to South Any Room. If you'd like to go out and spend a minute with Terry and the South Any Room, we'll continue with the business for this morning. But there'll be a time so you can do that. So thank you all for honoring Terry. Thank you, Terry Cindy. Shepherd's team. Thank you all for being here. So we'll move on. Thank you all. Y'all may be seated. As is our custom, we will begin our day with scripture reading and prayer by our chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. Our chaplain this morning will be introduced by the gentleman from the 170-second House District down in Motri, Georgia. I want you to vote for the little motriarch. I thought you were just making sure it is South Georgia. 170-second House District, gripping Chaz Cannon. Chaz. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Good morning, members of the House. I'm honored to share with you this morning the Reverend Dr. Hugh Ward from Motri, Georgia. Reverend Ward, or as most of us refer to him as Hugh B, was born in Jackson, Mississippi in 1940. He graduated from high school in 1958, went on to graduate from Asbury College and Wilmore, Kentucky in 1962. Soon after, he joined the United States Marine Corps. He was up in 1966 and was sent to language school to become an interrogator. Later, he deployed to Vietnam with the Third Marine Division in 1968. Reverend Ward later received a Master of Divinity degree from Columbia Theological Seminary and a Doctor of Ministry degree from the Graduate Theological Foundation. He served 22 years as a senior pastor at first Presbyterian Church, my family's church in Motri. The members of my family have been long-term members. There are a multitude of honors and accolades that Reverend Ward has received over as many years of service. Aside from those many honors, the most important to me is that he married Beth and me over 20 years ago. He's baptized both of my children and he prayed for me during some of my most difficult times and my diplomas to the Middle East. Reverend Ward, at the very youthful age of 84, continues to serve his community on a daily basis. His wife of many years died. He could not join us today, but she still sings in the choir every Sunday morning in Motri. They have two daughters, Mandy and Katie and five grandchildren. Ladies and gentlemen, I give you Reverend Hugh Ward. This probably is one of the greatest honors ever bestowed on me in my lifetime. And, Mr. Speaker, I've watched you on TV, but you look a lot better in person. I love you, man. And, second, I have to say how heartwarming it is to see the way that you obviously have held Terry Inland in your prayers and thoughts and such a warm welcome this morning. It does me good to see that here in the state capital. Mr. Speaker and members of the House, I'm grateful for the opportunity to speak to you this morning. I'm grateful to my state representative, Charles Cannon, or as we call him, Chaz. Chaz himself had a distinguished career in many venues in the classroom, on the athletic field, as graduate of West Point, the military academy, on the battlefield, in the Middle East, and now in the public arena. He's retired Army officer. His wife, Beth, is a registered nurse. His two brothers-in-law also served with distinction in the United States Army as well. But thank God their pastor is a United States Marine. And then, this is a word about your work, not my work here. I bring words of gratitude for my president and CEO of Cockett Regional Medical Center, Dr. James Matney, and from our foundation staff. Thank you for your unwavering support of the Georgia Heart Program. This program has enabled Cockett Regional Medical Center to expand its service lines, to bring several capital projects to fruition and assist with the care of our indigest patients. Our rural hospital has a feisty, effective Georgia Heart administrator named Gina Horn, MacDonald. She has outhustled every other healthcare facility in South Georgia, and she spread the good news about supporting our local hospital. I also applaud the work of my good friend Sam Watson, who's crossed the way there, former father, husband, to Emily, and an effective and devoted citizen. I want you to know something about my county, where I've been a part of for 35 years. It has given birth to some of our state's greatest endeavors, the Sun Belt Expo, and if you've never been there, I hope you'll come and see the great things that happen there. The most most diving tigers, Saxby Chameless, makes his home in military. A YMCA that comprises 65,000 square feet of space. The birthplace of a Marist Mike, which we knew is ABC Mike in the early days. A national recognized hospital, and the Philadelphia College of osteopathic medicine, and some of the finest churches that excelled in reaching out to a needy world. I love living in Cockett County. Representative Cannon's father-in-law, Frank Harrison, kidnapped me from Decatur, and brought me to an island of tranquility in Cockett County to pass to the First President's Church. But speaking to you this morning enables me to give you a testimony that I had always planned to be a preacher and a pastor. No, I'm here to confess to you that at one time I actually worked for a living. I pedaled chemicals for a major corporation, Ashland Chemical Company. One of my favorite purchasing agent was a man named Larry Moore at Masonite Corporation in Laurel, Mississippi. He had been a slabberjet pilot in Korea. But I'll be honest with you when I met him, he weighed as much as a slabberjet. And over lunch one day, in a small barbecue joint in Laurel, Larry looked over an ear of corn dripping with butter onto his paisley tie. And he said, what would you be doing if you weren't calling on me? I said, I'd be playing golf. And he said, no you idiot. What would you be doing if they were alive? And I said, that would be a different question. I would resign from Ashland and become a Presbyterian pastor. If you resign now, he said, this time next year you'll have a year behind you. And so I hear I am 53 years later before you. God speaks to us in a plethora of ways. And sometimes we listen. You, ladies and gentlemen, are one of the largest congregations I've ever addressed in my whole life as a minister. And ever since Mr. Cannon invited me to be your champion for this day, I have prayed mightily that you all would have wisdom encouraged to serve this great state fight. I believe you will all work for the welfare and happiness of all to see that justice and compassion are allotted to your folks back home and throughout the entire state. Look, I know, and you know we live in a beautiful but burdened world. And at times it appears that our poor bleeding world is stumbling from one blunder to another. But we, the citizens of your state, have elected you. Whom we believe possess a broad vision for tapping the wells of wisdom. A wisdom that leads us in these challenging days toward a future of peace and prosperity. And so though I am not your personal spiritual God, I'm here to encourage you and your labors. Praying you will help us all pass on to our children a better world than the one we received for God's good and God's glory. I pray that this day in your daily adventures, you'll love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul and with all your strength and your neighbor as yourself. I'd like to ask you to pause for a moment of silent prayer as you pray for Terry, as you pray for your constituents, as you pray for our state and our nation. Would you pause with me just for a quiet moment? O Lord our God, your love is unfailing and your mercies are renewed every morning. At this moment we lift up our souls to you as honestly and completely as possible. As we're able to do this, O Lord, fulfilling us what you long to accomplish, our freedom from sin and selfishness, our release from anxiety, lives tuned to truth and beauty, devotion and goodness. We know, O Lord, that you're the beginning and the end. You see the end from the beginning and you have seen, has seen us and been with us in all the ordinary moments of our life. You have laid your hand upon us in ways that are beyond our comprehension and because of this we have seen for ourselves in the extraordinary ways you're involved in the most ordinary moments of our lives. And we come to you. We come to you thinking of the rhythm of our lives. The daily routines we have here of sleeping and waking, of washing and dressing, of eating and saying goodbye, we come thinking of our work and the boredom and excitement that comes from our daily toll here in this howled place. In the midst of our thousands of wakings in the course of meeting our constituents and even in the fraction moments of our life, we know, O Lord, if you speak anywhere, it is here in the midst of our living. But it is in the cracks and crevices of our existence in the hairline fractions of our life we're not alone. We have come to know that you're the God of victory for us, for all of us. You're a victorious over sin and death. Those things which have a strangle hold on humanity. Because of you, we're awakened to a living hope that after every cross comes a resurrection, after every winter there is a spring. As we commit ourselves to you, let us go forth from this place with our confidence restored that compassion is able to conquer greed. That peace can overcome war, that love is stronger than hate, that life is miter than death. With that inspiration, let us arise and go into the world to find beauty and simplicity, to find riches and plain living, to find self-worth and self-giving for your sake, O Lord, we pray. I'm in. I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God, interdiscipline with liberty and justice for all. Awesome. Great message. Thank you. The door keeps you made a lot of doors. Members, you may join Brother Ward, Dr. Ward in the south any room, along with Chairman England, and just a moment. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.
